meta.notes: Guardian-style C2 multiple-choice sentences. Each item: q, options[4], answer (letter), topic.

sentences.q: If the government ______ more decisively during the crisis, the outcome might have been far less damaging.
Rarely ______ such a united response from communities that had long been divided.
The minister insisted that she ______ the data before the report was published.
Despite repeated setbacks, the campaign managed to ______ enough support to influence policy.
The controversial article was swiftly removed from the website, as it ______ to be inaccurate.
The journalist was praised for her ability to cut straight ______ the political spin.
The mayor was deeply concerned ______ the rise in youth unemployment.
Many leaders admit that ______ real change requires more than symbolic gestures.
Had the inspectors been swifter to intervene, the scandal ______ quite so widespread.
Seldom ______ such clear evidence presented in a corruption inquiry.
The spokesperson denied that the company ______ any knowledge of the breach prior to notification.
Volunteers were able to ______ the event together at very short notice.
The policy proposals were immediately ______ by opponents as politically motivated.
She was remarkably adept ______ negotiating tense meetings with foreign ministers.
The committee recommended ______ the report be revised before publication.
She avoided ______ comment, preferring to study the figures quietly.
If more funding ______ made available, the programme could be scaled up sharply.
Not only ______ the minister fail to consult colleagues, but she also concealed the correspondence.
The auditor reported that the balance sheet ______ adjusted to reflect contingent liabilities.
The campaign needed to ______ momentum if it hoped to change public opinion.
The draft legislation was described as fundamentally ______ to many stakeholders.
He was known for being consistently even-handed ______ disputes between departments.
I suggest ______ the timeline to allow for proper consultation.
The editorial implied that the policy, while well-intentioned, ______ poorly executed.
Were the transport strikes to continue, the economic cost ______ to mount rapidly.
Little ______ to suggest that the forecasts took full account of regional variation.
The chairman said that the firm ______ new governance measures by the year-end.
The organisers hoped to ______ enough volunteers to run the shelter throughout winter.
That proposal was subsequently ______ by independent reviewers for lacking rigour.
He was praised for being unafraid ______ challenge the received wisdom.
They advised ______ the proposal until further evidence emerged.
By the time the review concluded, several assumptions ______ thoroughly tested.
Had the evidence been disclosed earlier, public confidence ______ less severely eroded.
Not until the report appeared ______ the scale of the problem become apparent.
Her letter claimed that the department ______ the recommendations in full.
After a long campaign they finally managed to ______ enough signatures to trigger a review.
The dataset was subsequently ______ as incomplete and not fit for purpose.
The union representative was insistent ______ negotiating until acceptable terms were offered.
The committee supported ______ a specialist to oversee the audit process.
Had the test been conducted under identical conditions, the results ______ more comparable.
If the commission ______ the data sooner, the recommendations might have been different.
Rarely ______ such unanimity among experts on a matter of public policy.
The editor acknowledged that the facts ______ verified before publication.
Local groups worked to ______ a network of mutual aid during the emergency.
The draft was immediately ______ as lacking coherence and depth.
She was adept ______ reducing complex analysis to accessible summaries.
The authors recommended ______ further longitudinal study before policy change.
By then the initiative ______ its original urgency and required reassessment.
Were Parliament to adopt the proposals, the regulatory burden ______ markedly.
Not until witnesses testified ______ the committee alter its view of the affair.
He emphasised that the firm ______ all reasonable steps to mitigate the problem.
The volunteers were able to ______ a comprehensive relief package in days.
The plan, though ambitious, was ultimately judged ______ in its assumptions.
Her reputation rests heavily ______ integrity and professional rigour.
The board recommended ______ a specialist panel to advise on ethics.
We concluded that the model ______ to incorporate non-linear effects.
If evidence ______ to support the claim, the authors must revise their conclusion.
Rarely ______ a policy debate provoke so much constructive criticism.
The spokesperson maintained that the fund ______ properly allocated in the previous year.
Grassroots organisers tried to ______ support across neighbourhoods quickly.
The investigation concluded that the methodology was ______ to the task.
He distinguished himself ______ combining scholarship with practical judgement.
Their recommendation involved ______ further comparative studies across regions.
Following the audit, several practices ______ tightened to avoid recurrence.
Had ministers been more transparent, public outrage ______ less virulent.
No sooner ______ the inquiry begun than new allegations surfaced.
The director said the company ______ several remedial actions in response to the audit.
Community leaders sought to ______ a coalition to press for reform.
The policy was widely criticised as being overly ______ on optimistic assumptions.
She excelled ______ distilling technical arguments for a general readership.
They advocated ______ the pilot project before expanding it nationaly.
By the time regulators intervened, the practice ______ entrenched in the sector.
If investment ______ prioritised, the infrastructure deficit might be reduced.
Rarely ______ such a sustained programme of cross-party collaboration.
The report concluded that the agency ______ adequate oversight in prior years.
Volunteers helped to ______ an emergency fund within days of the appeal.
The authors were sharply critical of the methodology as being ______ applied.
She was lauded for being uncompromising ______ principle.
They recommended ______ a cross-disciplinary panel to review the evidence.
Following the inquiry, fewer anomalies ______ evident in subsequent audits.
Had the cautionary signs been heeded, the collapse ______ averted.
Little ______ to prepare stakeholders for the sudden policy shift.
He told the press that he ______ the figures earlier but they had been misinterpreted.
Local groups continue to ______ networks of mutual support across the city.
The panel found that the assumptions were insufficiently ______ for meaningful projection.
She was invaluable ______ mediating differences between departments.
The recommendation focused on ______ stakeholder input as a priority action.
By the time the new guidance was published, several practices ______ redundant.
If resources ______ reallocated, the pilot might be extended nationwide.
So rarely ______ such an unequivocal endorsement from the scientific community.
She conceded that the model ______ recalibrated in light of the new data.
Campaigners mobilised quickly to ______ momentum around the proposal.
The review concluded the methodology lacked sufficient empirical ______.
He remained sceptical ______ promises made by incoming ministers.
They suggested ______ a comparative framework to contextualise results.
In subsequent years the practice ______ gradually curtailed under new regulation.
Had the advisory panel been convened earlier, the outcome ______ different.
No sooner ______ the evidence presented than the committee demanded answers.
He insisted that the entity ______ its responsibilities transparently.
Organisers worked tirelessly to ______ a grassroots movement for change.
The auditor flagged that the assumptions were insufficiently ______ for projection.
She excelled ______ translating technical detail into policy recommendations.
The paper recommended ______ broader consultative processes prior to adoption.
By the end of the review several practices ______ been rendered obsolete.
If judges ______ the new evidence, the case might be reopened.
Seldom ______ any minister deliver such a candid defence in public.
The chief executive acknowledged that earlier warnings ______ overlooked.
Volunteers pooled resources to ______ an emergency distribution network.
The committee described the modelling as inherently ______ and in need of revision.
He was praised for being unafraid ______ voice uncomfortable truths.
They advised ______ the initiative pending evaluation of early indicators.
At that point, the risk profile ______ materially altered by subsequent events.
Had the early indicators been heeded, the downturn ______ been less pronounced.
No sooner ______ the committee published its findings than the markets reacted.
She asserted that the team ______ rigorous review before endorsing the conclusion.
Neighbours organised quickly to ______ mutual aid across the borough.
The scheme was criticised for resting on ______ assumptions about uptake.
He distinguished himself ______ bringing conflicting parties to consensus.
They recommended ______ a phased approach to implementation.
Following that stage, several practices ______ redundant and were discontinued.
sentences.topic: Past Simple vs Past Perfect nuance

sentences.q: If the committee ______ clearer guidance, decision-makers might act more confidently.
Seldom ______ ministers face such sustained scrutiny without resigning.
The director claimed the firm ______ appropriate measures following the inquiry.
The charity mobilised local resources to ______ immediate relief to affected families.

She took pains ______ separate analysis from partisan debate.
They urged ______ further baseline studies before committing resources.
By the time oversight was introduced, several risky practices ______ established.
Had the data been more robust, policy-makers ______ more decisive steps.
Little ______ to indicate the projections had accounted for demographic change.
The statement affirmed that the department ______ corrective action immediately.
Residents organised to ______ support for the displaced families.
The analysis was judged sufficiently ______ to inform next year's budget.
He became known for being unflinchingly candid ______ policy failures.
Experts recommended ______ a rolling evaluation to track outcomes over time.
By then the problem ______ systemic and required structural remedies.
If external auditors ______ invited earlier, issues might have been flagged sooner.
Seldom ______ a report gain such immediate traction across the sector.

Civil society groups campaigned to ______ public awareness of the scheme.
The reviewer described the approach as theoretically sound but practically ______.

They proposed ______ a panel to oversee independent monitoring.

Experts recommended ______ further comparative analysis across jurisdictions.
After those reforms, the process ______ more resilient to shocks.
If oversight mechanisms ______ strengthened, many problems could be averted.
Seldom ______ policy advice so widely debated at the municipal level.
The advocate insisted that the plan ______ reviewed in full before adoption.
Local activists succeeded in ______ cross-community dialogue at pace.
The research team found the dataset insufficiently ______ to support claims.
He earned praise ______ resisting short-term political pressure.
They proposed ______ a longitudinal panel to monitor outcomes reliably.
By the next review, governance standards ______ notably improved.
Had the risk modelling been more conservative, contingency funds ______ larger.
No sooner ______ the evidence compiled than the committee acted.
The chair explained that they ______ proactive steps after the initial review.
Neighbourhood groups rallied to ______ mutual aid in the aftermath.

She distinguished herself ______ impartiality and intellectual rigour.
They advocated ______ a staged implementation to manage risk.
Following the reforms, systemic weaknesses ______ progressively addressed.
If external audit had been routine, irregularities ______ detected earlier.
Seldom ______ a single study prompt such a policy rethink.
He admitted that management ______ lapses in oversight during the period.
Campaigners sought to ______ grassroots momentum before election season.
The draft guidance was characterised as technically ______ but sparsely evidenced.
He insisted on being judged ______ his track record rather than promises.
The report urged ______ the pilot before scaling up regionally.
Subsequent monitoring found compliance ______ steadily increasing.
Had the advisory group been heeded, the programme ______ more resilient.
No sooner ______ the new rules introduced than confusion ensued.
The statement indicated the firm ______ steps to remedy the deficiencies.
Local volunteers pooled skills to ______ a makeshift centre for victims.
The evaluation described the evidence base as insufficiently ______ to justify expansion.
She was praised ______ steering a coherent response in difficult circumstances.
They recommended ______ an independent audit to validate the findings.
By the next quarter, outcomes ______ showing modest improvement.
If contingency plans ______ implemented, disruption could have been mitigated.
Seldom ______ a policy proposal provoke such immediate scrutiny.
The board conceded that earlier warnings ______ insufficiently acted upon.
Advocates mobilised resources to ______ an outreach programme over winter.
The methodology was criticised as being overly ______ in its assumptions.
He was resolute ______ defending the independence of the inquiry.
They urged ______ rigorous monitoring to ensure fidelity of rollout.
Subsequent examinations found documentation ______ markedly improved.
Had leadership responded proactively, reputational damage ______ limited.
No sooner ______ the data released than analysts flagged inconsistencies.
She confirmed that the team ______ all recommended changes prior to rollout.
Community groups worked to ______ capacity for emergency response locally.
The analysis was judged technically sound but operationally ______.

They recommended ______ iterative pilots before national roll-out.
As monitoring intensified, compliance ______ slowly improved.
If the regulator ______ firmer action, market confidence might have recovered sooner.
Seldom ______ ministers appear so prepared to accept independent advice.
The CEO acknowledged that controls ______ inadequate in earlier years.
Volunteers coordinated efforts to ______ relief distribution across regions.
Reviewers characterised the assumptions as overly ______ and untested.
She insisted on being assessed ______ her record rather than campaign rhetoric.
The report urged ______ a standing panel to oversee progress regularly.
In later reviews, the controls ______ gradually strengthened.
Had the oversight been in place earlier, the irregularities ______ contained.
No sooner ______ the new guidance released than practitioners sought clarification.

Community networks mobilised to ______ immediate shelter and support.
The draft was criticised as theoretically elegant but practically ______.

They recommended ______ pilot studies to validate assumptions empirically.
Subsequent audits showed compliance ______ materially improved.
If clearer guidelines ______ issued, ambiguity in interpretation would fall.
Seldom ______ reports provoke such sustained public scrutiny and debate.
